On 2008-06-09, at 07:23 , Phil Surette wrote:

> I'd like to make a case for adding logging of assertions into junit.
> I've been using junit for many years, and something that I've found
> both for myself and for people who I've mentored in XP practices is
> that it is often helpful to get warm fuzzy feedback that your tests
> are running and asserting what you think they are asserting.
>
> I notice that I'm not alone in this; I see there are several threads
> where people were looking for this feature
> (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17845 "how to log
> junit tests", http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/18762
> "junit 4 & logging",
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/12000 "Log4J Logging
> in JUnit")
>
I am just going to be frank here. Yes, many people have said they want  
to log assertions in tests because they want the warm fuzzy feedback  
that their tests are running and assertion what they think they are  
asserting. Logging is just one, and in my opinion a bad, way to do  
this. I believe it is much better to write simpler tests.
> 1) eliminating redundant logging statements - Many logging statements
> in a JUnit test case simply output information that you've already
> told JUnit about in your assertions. Developers often put these in as
> a 'sanity check' to verify that the test is doing what they expected.
>
If your tests need such a sanity check, then I believe they should be  
simpler.
> 2) improving assertion messages - it's often the case that the
>
> first time you see the message for an assertion will be when the
> assertion fails, which may not happen until you run a regression test
> many moons after you coded the test. Unless you see the message
> displayed when you are developing the test, you won't realize that the
> message - if you provided one - is not be very helpful. Better
> assertion messages also help to communicate to a developer what the
> point of the assertion is both when it fails and when reading the  
> test.
>
If you aren't going to think about the failure message when you write  
it, then don't write one.
> 3) see finer-grain test results. Every assertion is a mini-test on its
> own, but JUnit these mini-tests are invisible until they fail.
>
Absolutely not. Assertions are not mini-tests. A test is a test. If  
you have multiple unrelated assertions in a test, then move them into  
their own tests. This leads to a number of benefits (more accurate  
test count metrics, more information when a test fails, easier to  
isolate the cause of a failure).
> 4) by making logging easy, it can help to avoid the
> using-system-outs-instead-of-asserts syndrome, where new junit test
> writers will write "test cases" that actually just write a bunch of
> stuff to the console that the test writer then eyeballs for expected
> results
>
Why would anyone use JUnit to spit things out to the console? If they  
want output on the console, and they're not just using that as a way  
to learn to use JUnit, then they shouldn't use JUnit.
> There are some problems with logging assertions that I have  
> encountered:
>
> 1) if iterating over a collection and asserting each element, your log
> can be overwhelmed. Maybe it would be useful to have some way of
> hinting that a particular assertion should not create notifications;
> maybe not.
>
I don't even want to think about how slowly tests will run, and how  
much time I would waste deciding which tests should log what and when.  
It's much easier just to add logging where I want it.
> Is there any appetite out there for adding assertion logging (or
> assertion notification) into the junit 4 framework? I would be
> happy to do the work if I thought it would be accepted into the
> main junit distribution. Or maybe this capability already exists
> in some way in junit 4 that I am not aware of?
>
Yes, there is such an appetite, but I hope there is a bigger appetite  
not to include it.
